meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Saylor
meeting_annotations.transcript: and like the um the temporal resolution versus spatial resolution like that type of thing and then also the limitations in the behavioral essays like what are we actually interrogating here? Are we looking at a behavior that is related to a disorder or condition like depression or are we just you know, looking at a normal thing that C elegans happen to do and I don't have any answers for that. And I love model systems.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I mean, you know, with flies, we're certainly not going to say that like a fly is depressed or a fly has Alzheimer's disease, but we can say like is there a difference in the accumulation of tau in the brain, um, you know, as a molecular readout, but we certainly are not going to, you know, we can say is there impaired memory in an appetitive memory essay, um, you know, so we can we can look at specific phenotypic readouts that may correlate with a disease state, but we can't we would never call it that disease state of fly, you know, a fly can't have Alzheimer's.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Bendlin
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Cologna
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, I think there's also an element in which in in most of these cases, right? There's genetic risk factors, but they're not genetically driven diseases. And you know, some of our, you know, like, you know, the AD mouse models, for example, right? You can go on forever about all the caveats associated with the AD mouse model. So I think with all of these models, um, you know, it seems to me there's a limitation that we actually don't really have a great um setup all the time even to start to ask some of the questions you want to, which maybe is what drives so many people to look at humans.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Bendlin
meeting_annotations.transcript: Mhm.

meeting_annotations.transcript: And then the other thought I I had which was kind of off of Rachel's comment, you know, I do a lot of proteomics, right? So, um, you know, when you start thinking about exotic model systems, I mean, obviously not zebra fish flies or mice, but um, this is a limitation if you're looking at proteins. If you're looking at metabolites are with is in there pretty well known and that's different. Just a thought.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, you raise a really important point, which is just about what are the best models for certain and then if you're studying disease, uh, and then will that translate to humans? meeting_annotations.speaker: Melanie Gareau
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh, we don't worry about that. Um, actually our bigger concern is behavior. Um, so when you change the investigator, it will stress out the animal.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Melanie Gareau
meeting_annotations.transcript: So we we have to control for that when we do our behavior studies.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Melanie Gareau
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, to make sure that they're handled by the same person and that there's um but they can get changes in behavior pretty easily.

meeting_annotations.transcript: But on the other other hand, are there any simpler model? Are there any model that we don't need to kill a mouse um or take it out?

meeting_annotations.transcript: So then you can start seeing them differentiate into.
